quoteTime: about nine o'clock in the morning
quoteLast: when Bruce entered Gondar, and every person he met in the street wore the countenance of a condemned malefactor. The ras went immediately to the palace with the king, who retired, as usual, to a kind of cage or lattice window, where he always sits unseen when in council.
title: The Life and Adventures of Bruce, the African Traveller
author: Head, Francis Bond, Sir, 1793-1875

quoteLast: I was ordered by Colonel Burn-Murdoch of the Royal Dragoons to bring my guns up to his entrenched camp behind the bridge to assist in its defence. I had breakfast with him and he seemed very nice.
title: With the Naval Brigade in Natal, 1899-1900: Journal of Active Service
author: Burne, C. R. N. (Charles Richard Newdigate), 1873-1940

quoteTime: about nine o'clock in the morning
quoteLast: , I remember, for just then the captain called to me to stand by the chronometer while he took his fore observation. Captain Hackstaff wasn't one of those old skippers who do everything themselves with a pocket watch, and keep the key of the chronometer in their waistcoat pocket, and won't tell the mate how far the dead reckoning is out.
title: Man Overboard!
author: Crawford, F. Marion (Francis Marion), 1854-1909

quoteFirst: Here La Marmora placed the flower of his army, the Sardinian and Lombard Grenadiers, the latter commanded by Prince Amedeo. The fighting continued through the day over very widely distributed ground, but from
quoteLast: the supreme interest was concentrated at and near Custoza, in which the Archduke promptly detected the turning-point of the battle. To wrest Custoza from the hold of the Italians was to the Austrians on the 24th of June 1866, what the taking of the crest of Solferino had been to the French on the 24th of June 1859.
title: The Liberation of Italy, 1815-1870
author: Martinengo-Cesaresco, Evelyn Lilian Hazeldine Carrington, contessa, 1852-1931

quoteTime: about nine o’clock in the morning
quoteLast: he discovered that his host kept an oil-shop.
title: New Grub Street
author: Gissing, George, 1857-1903

quoteFirst: So it happened that, as the colonel had foreseen and arranged, Stephanie traveled across the mimic Beresina
quoteTime: about nine o’clock in the morning
quoteLast: , and was awakened by an explosion of rockets about a hundred paces from the scene of action. It was a signal. Hundreds of peasants raised a terrible clamor, like the despairing shouts that startled the Russians when twenty thousand stragglers learned that by their own fault they were delivered over to death or to slavery.
title: Farewell
author: Balzac, Honoré de, 1799-1850; Marriage, Ellen, 1865-1946 [Translator]

quoteTime: about nine o’clock in the morning
quoteLast: when Dubois found the two Directors, Gohier and Moulins, and asked for the order to arrest Bonaparte. While they were in doubt and hesitating, the secretary of the Directory, Lagarde, stated that he would not countersign such an order unless three Directors signed it.
title: Napoleon: A Sketch of His Life, Character, Struggles, and Achievements

quoteLast: of the day on which we entered Rouen, we were halted at a village on the banks of the Seine, in order to procure refreshment, and yet all we could get were eggs and bread. But if an egg is to be eaten with a spoon, the spoon must bear some proportion to the egg: here, however, we were supplied with pewter spoons of no ordinary dimensions.
title: My adventures during the late war
author: O'Brien, Donat Henchy, 1785-1857; Oman, Charles, 1860-1946 [Editor]

quoteFirst: The construction of the trench was not without its effect upon the gang of villains at Morris's.

title: The Cruise of the Jasper B.

quoteFirst: We were expecting to be in action every day, but nothing was seen of the enemy till the 26th, when we came upon him at
quoteLast: in the railway station near Viljoen’s Drift, half a mile from the Vaal River. There some time was spent in reconnoitring to find out the enemy’s strength, and when a few shells had been put into the station, turning out only a hundred Boers, we were too late to stop the train which had apparently been loading up there.
title:
The History of Lumsden's Horse
A Complete Record of the Corps from Its Formation to Its Disbandment

quoteFirst: Pneumonia and pleurisy and a touch of meningitis. Alvina drank her tea, took a little breakfast, and went to bed at
quoteTime: about nine o’clock in the morning
quoteLast: , leaving James in charge of Miss Pinnegar. Time was all deranged.
title: The Lost Girl
author: Lawrence, D. H. (David Herbert), 1885-1930

quoteFirst: In an autobiographical work, entitled "What I Remember," by her son, Thomas Adolphus Trollope, we get some touching pictures of this wonderful woman writing her books. He speaks of her passing an extended period by the bedside of her invalid son. From
quoteLast: until eight in the evening, with "a cheerful countenance and a bleeding heart," she entertained and nursed her patient. He generally slept about eight, when she went to her desk and wrote her fiction to amuse light-hearted readers.
title: Literary Byways
author: Andrews, William, 1848-1908

quoteTime: About nine o'clock in the morning
quoteLast: when we went to see what work we would do, ol' man Wright called us all up and told us to come together. Then he told us we were free. I couldn't get nothing to do; so I jus' stayed on and made a crop."
title: Slave Narratives: A Folk History of Slavery in the United States from Interviews with Former Slaves, Volume II, Arkansas Narratives, Part 1
author: United States. Work Projects Administration

quoteFirst: During this last voyage I had no commerce with the master or any of his men; but, pretending I was sick, kept close in my cabin. On the fifth of December, 1715, we cast anchor in the Downs,
quoteLast: , and at three in the afternoon I got safe to my house at Rotherhith. [546]
title: Gulliver's Travels into Several Remote Nations of the World
author: Swift, Jonathan, 1667-1745

quoteFirst: The steamers _Khedive_ and _Nyanza_, the latter towing a lighter, appeared to-day
quoteLast: , bringing 80 soldiers, with the Major and Adjutant of the 2nd Battalion, and 130 carriers of the Madi tribe. We received gifts of raki (ten-gallon demijohn, a kind of Russian vodka, from the Pasha's distillery, pomegranates, oranges, water-melons, and more onions, besides six sheep, four goats, and a couple of strong donkeys, one for myself and one for Doctor Park).
title: In Darkest Africa, Vol. 1; or, The Quest, Rescue, and Retreat of Emin, Governor of Equatoria
author: Stanley, Henry M. (Henry Morton), 1841-1904
